DataElement.preferredName: BCR-ABL1 Fusion Protein Expression Molecular Genetic Technique Or Cytogenetic Analysis Detection Status Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The positive, negative or unknown text that describes the presence or absence of BCR-ABL1 fusion detected by FISH, PCR or cytogenetics.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: BCR-ABL1 Fusion Protein Expression Molecular Genetic Technique Or Cytogenetic Analysis Detection Status
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Bcr/abl is the gene rearrangement that is associated primarily with the disease chronic myelogenous leukemia and less frequently with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This rearrangement results in the formation of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein._The methods and tools used for DNA analysis and manipulation._Or; used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities._The activity of perceiving, discerning, discovering or identifying._A condition or state at a particular time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Bcr/abl is the gene rearrangement that is associated primarily with the disease chronic myelogenous leukemia and less frequently with acute lymphoblastic leukemia. This rearrangement results in the formation of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein.

Concepts.definition: Bcr/abl is the gene rearrangement that is associated primarily with the disease chronic myelogenous leukemia and less frequently with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.  This rearrangement results in the formation of the BCR-ABL1 fusion protein.

Concepts.definition: The methods and tools used for DNA analysis and manipulation.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Techniques for analysis of chromosomal and subchromosomal properties and structures, such as those to diagnose, classify, screen for, or manage genetic diseases and abnormalities.
The act of perceiving, discerning, discovering, or identifying.
